title.value: An Empirical Study of Self-Admitted Technical Debt in Machine Learning Software
title.justification: The title of the paper is extracted from the provided abstract.
title.quote: An Empirical Study of Self-Admitted Technical Debt in Machine Learning Software

extractions.description: The paper focuses on Self-Admitted Technical Debt (SATD) in Machine Learning software. The authors analyze 318 open-source ML projects across five domains and compare them to 318 non-ML projects. They investigate the prevalence, composition, location, and evolution of SATD, finding that ML projects have a higher percentage of SATD compared to non-ML projects. The study reveals that ML pipeline components for data preprocessing and model generation are more prone to debt, and SATDs appear earlier in ML projects. The research also explores the characteristics of long-lasting SATDs, providing insights for ML practitioners and researchers.

type.justification: The paper conducts an empirical study on SATD in ML software.
type.quote: This paper aims to investigate the occurrence of SATD in ML code by analyzing 318 open-source ML projects across five domains, along with 318 non-ML projects.

name.justification: The paper focuses on technical debt in machine learning software, implying machine learning as the primary research field.
name.quote: This paper aims to investigate the occurrence of SATD in ML code by analyzing 318 open-source ML projects across five domains, along with 318 non-ML projects.

name.justification: The paper investigates SATD in self-driving car systems, identifying it as one of the application domains.
name.quote: This paper aims to fill this gap in the literature by studying SATD in ML-based systems belonging to five popular domains, i.e., self-driving car, audio processing, autonomous gameplay, image processing and natural language processing.

name.justification: The paper investigates SATD in audio processing, identifying it as one of the application domains.
name.quote: This paper aims to fill this gap in the literature by studying SATD in ML-based systems belonging to five popular domains, i.e., self-driving car, audio processing, autonomous gameplay, image processing and natural language processing.

name.justification: The paper investigates SATD in autonomous gameplay, identifying it as one of the application domains.
name.quote: This paper aims to fill this gap in the literature by studying SATD in ML-based systems belonging to five popular domains, i.e., self-driving car, audio processing, autonomous gameplay, image processing and natural language processing.

name.quote: This paper aims to fill this gap in the literature by studying SATD in ML-based systems belonging to five popular domains, i.e., self-driving car, audio processing, autonomous gameplay, image processing and natural language processing.

name.quote: This paper aims to fill this gap in the literature by studying SATD in ML-based systems belonging to five popular domains, i.e., self-driving car, audio processing, autonomous gameplay, image processing and natural language processing.

name.justification: SVM is mentioned as a traditional ML model.
name.quote: Using a traditional ML model, say SVM, for image classification would require manual feature extraction (e.g., SIFT).

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not mention any contribution related to SVM.

is_executed.justification: The paper suggests using SVM for image classification, implying its execution.
is_executed.quote: Using a traditional ML model, say SVM, for image classification would require manual feature extraction (e.g., SIFT).

is_compared.justification: The paper compares SVM to Deep Learning models for image classification.
is_compared.quote: Using a traditional ML model, say SVM, for image classification would require manual feature extraction (e.g., SIFT). Paying off this TD by upgrading SVM to a Deep Learning model like CNN can itself cause massive ripple effects across multiple components of Amershi’s ML pipeline [3], with heavy financial and technical cost.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific paper is referenced for SVM.

name.justification: CNN is mentioned as a Deep Learning model.
name.quote: Paying off this TD by upgrading SVM to a Deep Learning model like CNN can itself cause massive ripple effects across multiple components of Amershi’s ML pipeline [3], with heavy financial and technical cost.

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not mention any contribution related to CNN.

is_executed.justification: The paper mentions using CNN for image classification, implying its execution.
is_executed.quote: Paying off this TD by upgrading SVM to a Deep Learning model like CNN can itself cause massive ripple effects across multiple components of Amershi’s ML pipeline [3], with heavy financial and technical cost.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares CNN to SVM for image classification.
is_compared.quote: Using a traditional ML model, say SVM, for image classification would require manual feature extraction (e.g., SIFT). Paying off this TD by upgrading SVM to a Deep Learning model like CNN can itself cause massive ripple effects across multiple components of Amershi’s ML pipeline [3], with heavy financial and technical cost.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific paper is referenced for CNN.

name.justification: The paper mentions Scikit-Learn as a popular ML toolkit used by developers.
name.quote: The advent of popular ML toolkits, such as Scikit-Learn, TensorFlow, and Auto ML, has enabled developers to easily leverage state-of-the-art ML algorithms to quickly develop ML-based systems with minimal overhead.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No paper is referenced as the source for Scikit-learn.

name.justification: The paper mentions TensorFlow and Auto ML as open-source ML libraries used by developers.
name.quote: The emergence of open-source ML libraries such as TensorFlow and Google Auto ML has enabled developers to harness state-of-the-art ML algorithms with minimal overhead.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No paper is referenced as the source for TensorFlow.

name.justification: Keras is mentioned as a potential library to use when migrating from Sklearn SVM to a CNN.
name.quote: In fact, 3) changes could even permeate in the deployment environment to generate inferences and parse predictions from a model from a different library (say, Sklearn SVM migration to Keras CNN), which could potentially even lead to changes in the deployment server, perhaps even at the client’s end.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No paper is referenced as the source for Keras.
